texts.shortText:
Adults in breeding plumage have a full black cap extending from base of bill, through bottom of eye to nape of neck, where extended into a crest. Bill long, thin and black with a characteristic yellow tip. Back and upper wings ash-grey, outer wing feathers dark. Rump, neck and belly white. Eyes very dark brown, legs and feet black.

In non-breeding plumage the forehead becomes white and the black cap much less pronounced.
Total length 36-41 cm, wingspan 95-105 cm, mass 190-230 g, sexes alike.

Global: Breeds in Western Europe and North America, non-breeding in Southern Africa and South America.

Local/Regional: Widely distributed along entire coastline, with greatest numbers on West Coast.

Does not breed in South Africa, but migrates here in southern summer, arriving about September and leaving by about March. Totally marine and rarely found inland. May form mixed flocks with other terns. Mostly found on mixed sandy and rocky coastlines with clear, shallow water. May bathe in shallow salt water, but rarely swims.
Hunts a variety of small fish up to 120 mm long, also crustaceans and molluscs.

Breeds in Europe and North America, not in South Africa. Start nesting at age 3-4. Nest a shallow scrap on the ground sometimes lined with debris, often positioned among other nesting terns. Eggs 1-2, rarely 3, green, heavily speckled and blotched with black and brown; incubated by both parents for 21-29 days. Chicks make first flight 28-32 days, but may remain with parents a further 4 months
Fairly easily identified by the long, thin, black bill with its yellow tip.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 455).
